awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Deployment of Laser Induced Breakdown Spectroscopy System from ROV Jason
awd_abstract_narration:
This project supports the test deployment of a completed laser induced breakdown spectroscopy (LIBS) system at seafloor hydrothermal vents using the remotely operated vehicle Jason as the support platform. Jason serves to align and orient the LIBS system using a three degree-of-freedom mechanical platform, and also provides high data rate bidirectional communication with the spectrometer. The testing will be based on two scientific use cases that are highly relevant to hydrothermal vents in a generic (i.e., not site specific) sense: the study of near-critical behavior of vent fluids and understanding chemical variability over a tidal cycle. Upon validation, the LIBS system will be made available to the hydrothermal vent science community.

LIBS utilizes a laser focused to a beam 10 cm in diameter that creates a plasma once the breakdown threshold of the material is exceeded. A gated spectrometer covering the near infrared to ultraviolet range is used to capture the plasma spectrum and hence the elemental composition. LIB operates on solids, liquids, gases and aerosols, and has been shown to operate under deep ocean pressure conditions. A real-time, non-invasive, simultaneously multi-elemental chemical sensing capability such as LIBS that does not require sample preparation would be a significant advance over current oceanographic technology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The purpose of this project is deployment and testing of a LIBS spectrometer using the ROV Jason as a platform, with immediate application to hydrothermal vent systems at mid-ocean ridges. The key deliverable of the work is a tested, validated, and documented prototype LIBS system that works with Jason and is extensible to autonomous operation at ocean observatories in the future. Two relevant scientific problems to the understanding of mid-ocean ridge hydrothermal vent systems were used to illustrate the scientific merits of the LIBS approach and guide the laboratory studies. The first of these requires in situ observations of vent fluid chemistry using LIBS to study phase separation and provide insight into the processes that have occurred along the hydrothermal flow path through the oceanic crust. This type of experiment requires the real-time, simultaneous measurements that LIBS provides. The second is investigating tidal deformation that may perturb permeability and fluid flow—fundamental controls on water-rock reactions that determine the chemical composition of hydrothermal fluids. This requires in situ measurements to determine short time scale fluctuations in vent fluid chemistry that have not been possible to date. The main job of the USC group was to support the instrument deployment by testing design concepts and issues as they develop, and studying optimal timing parameters for selected analytes at relevant ocean pressures. 

Lithium is a key analyte for our studies, as it is relevant to the proposed deep-ocean hydrothermal vent characterization. In the early part of the project the USC group developed a high pressure LIBS system that was used to optimize the measuerment condtions for Li, Na, K and other key analytes in seawater at pressures above 300 bar. This system was used as a prototype for the design of the sea deployable instrument at WHOI. In fundamental studies with this system the USC group studied single- and double-pulse (DP) LIBS for key analytes, determining that single-pulse LIBS provided the optimal results for Li, Na and K. The double-pulse LIBS studies lead to a model of how DP LIBS provided enhanced sensitivity for certain analytes in water up to 90 bar. More recent dynamic studies improved our understanding of LIBS measurements in flowing solutions, and how flow rate affected LIBS calibrations over a range of pressures. In these studies the effects of laser pulse rate and solution flow rate on the determination of lithium at high pressure for water and 2.5% NaCl solutions using LIBS were made.
